div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7287] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
THE PEACE. Excitement at Portsmouth. SPEECHES BY PLENIPOTENTIARIES. Demonstration at tokio.

div.p: A volley of guns announced the signing of the peace treaty at 8.47 p.m. The church bells at Portsmouth and Newcastle were rang, and flags were hung out everywhere.

After the treaty had been signed, M. Rosen and M. Komura delivered cordial speeches, expressing the wish that the two countries would remain good friends. The representatives of the two nations shook hands. (Reuter)

M. Maartens, in an interview after the signa-ture of peace, said that Russia will not brood over the past, but will gather all her forces a new struggle, not on the battlefield, but in the fields of social and political progress. (R.)
The town is decorated with flags in honor of the signing of the peace treaty.The Japanese plenipotentiaries have left (Havas)

A meeting held here yesterday protested against the terms of peace, and attacked the offices of the Government organ "Kokumin." Several people were injured and a number of arrests have been made. (Reuter)

div.head: ARMENIANS IN ATHENS. BOMB DEPOTS DISCOVERED.

div.p: The police have discovered several large depots of bombs, rifles, and cartridges, notably the cellar of the Armenian Church. An investigation leads to the belief that a widespread Armenian plot to induce the intervention of Europe in favor of Armenia has been unearthed. The object of this plot seems to have been to terrorise the Turks. Twelve Armenians have been arrested. (Reuter)
An important Armenian organisation has been discovered, which desires to induce European intervention in Turkish affairs. (H.)

div.head: TARTARS IN THE CAUCASUS. A REIGN OF TERROR.

div.p: Bands of Tartars are devastating the south-east. of the Caucasus province, assassinating and pillaging everywhere. Official reports admit that 200 people have been killed and wounded in the fights at Shusha, which is now on fire. The quarter where the factories and petrol refinery are situated is also on fire. (R.)
The Tartars are terrorising the south-east of Transcaucasia. (Havas)
The official bulletin notifies ninety cases of cholera and twenty-six deaths. (Havas)
The Channel Squadron has sailed. (Reuter)
Players beat Gentlemen by an innings and 196 runs. The rest of the matches for this date were drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: The Plaque
div.p: Yesterday a bulletin reports the death of a native street cleaner of the Labban quarter.

div.head: Child Discovered
div.p: A newborn child, alive and apparently healthy, was found last night in the Rue dee Soeurs and has been taken to hospital.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in — Ismailieh quarter of Cairo during to morrow might and at dawn of the 9th inst will poisoned by the police.

div.head: Counterfeit Marks
div.p: A goldsmith named Khalil Zeitoun was arrested yesterday on the charge of counterfeiting the Government hallmarks on gold and silver articles.

div.head: Ex-Empoye sentenced
div.p: The Gizeh native Court has condemned Moh. Ragbeb, ex-caretaker of the Maadi station, to six months imprisonment and L.E. 60 fine for embezzlement.

div.head: Suez canal
div.p: 13 vessels passed through the Canal on the 4th inst, 8 of which were British, 3 German, 1 French, 1 Dutch. The day's receipts were frs. 432,393.75, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,150,561.83.

div.head: Gambling Hell Raided
div.p: On Monday evening the police made a successful descent on a a gambling hell kept by a native in the Boulac quarter. The usual proces-verbal has been drawn up and the roulette board, etc. seized.

div.head: The Legislative Council
div.p: A meeting of the Legislative Council will be held on October 1, udner the presidency of Abdul Hamid Pasha Sadik, when the questions connected with the Armenian Church in Egypt will be discussed.

div.head: A Father's Cruelty
div.p: A native, named Mustapha Hassan, of Minet el Bassal, yesterday inflicted such a severe flogging on his son, who is barely four years of age, that the child fainted and had to be taken to hospital The unnatural parent has been arrested.

div.head: Departure of the Royal Berkshire regt
div.p: We learn that the A C.C. is giving an at home at the Cricket Club to the officers of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regt, on Friday, the 15th inst., on the occasion of cricket match between the regiment and the club.

div.head: Sudan Irrigation
div.p: The "Nineteenth Century and After" for September contains a long and most interesting article by Sir William Garstin on the Irrigation of the Sudan and the new engineering schemes for the Upper Nile which are now being examined and discussed. We hope to give our readers the fall text of the most important article in the near future.

div.head: Harmful soap
div.p: One of our Cairo contem-poraries states that the sanitary administration has decided to take vigorous measures to prevent the sale of soaps containing salicylate of soda, which remove dirt from the skin and after a while remove the skin as well. All manufacturers of these poisonous soaps will be prosecuted and the soap seised.

div.head: Delivery of Mails at Akhmin
div.p: Much disatisfaction is expressed at the late hoar at which the mails arrive at Akhmin. The usual time at which they arrive is 8.30 am. but there is no reason why they should not be here an hoar earlier and be ready for distribution at 8 am. It is to be hoped that the notice of the Postal authorities will be drawn to this, and that they will arrange for an advanced hour of delivery.

div.head: Fraudulent Broker
div.p: Taking a leaf out of the books of the Mariout Bedouin, a native broker recently sold a plot of land at Ibrahim-ieh, which he asserted to be his property, to a confiding client named El Bayed Mohamed El Gayar, who paid L.E 438.70 for what he probably imagined would be an excellent site. On discovering the fraud the victim complained to the authorities. A proces-verbal has been drawn up against the broker and handed over to the Parquet.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Abdul Halim Pasha Assim has returned to Alexandria, after presiding ovar the meeting of the Superior Council of the Wakfa Administration, which met at Cairo on Tuesday.
The Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General left Alexandria for Cairo yesterday afternoon.
We are authorised to contradict the rumour that Mr. Trevithick, chief of the Locomotive Department of the State Railways, is about to retire from the service on pension.
Mr. Richmond, of the Ministry of Public Works, has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo.
Ibrahim Bey Ali arrived here this morning.
General Sir E. Forestier-Walker, the newly-appointed Governor of Gibraltar, left London for that place last Friday by the P. and O. teamship Mongolia.

div.head: H. H. THE KHEDIVE.
WILL PROBABLY VISIT SUDAN.
div.p: Several of our native contemporaries state that H.H. the Khedive will visit the Sudan in the middle of February next to preside over the opening of the new Nile-Red Sea railway between Berber and Port Sudan.

div.head: SULTAN'S ACCESSION ANNIVERSARY.
div.p: Othman Pasha Ghalil, president of the committee of the Sultan's accession fetes' has received a letter from Nouri Bey, secretary to Mukhtar Pasha el Ghazi, Ottoman Commissioner, tendering H.I.M. the Sultan's thanks for the loyal manner in which the committee undertook the organisation of the fetes in celebration of the anniversary of his accession to the throne of Turkey.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LIMITED.
div.p: The order for goods wagons for use on the Nile-Khargeh Railway, now in course of construction under the supervision of Messre. Kincaid, Waller, Manville and Dawson, the consulting engineers to the Corporation, has been placed with the Metropolitan Amalgamated Railway Carriage and Wagon Co., Ltd., who tendered for the supply.

div.head: THE SOLAR ECLIP8E.
div.p: The "Times" gives the following account of the solar eclipse as viewed from Assouan

The eclipse was successfully observed here in a normal clear sky. The British party, with invaluable assistance from Captain Lyons and the officers of the Survey Department, obtained five ordinary exposures with an astrographic telescope, besides one with a green colour screen and one enlargement, six photographs polarized by reflection in a horizontal plane, and two in a vertical plane. Mr. Gunther, of Magdalen College, Oxford, obtained six plates with a Goerz lens for comparison with similar plates taken in Lahrador.

Mr. Reynolds's 120ft reflector was mounted under unforeseen difficulties, at short notice, with the able assistance of Mr. Keeling, of the survey, who has helped all the expeditions from the first. The local fire brigade kindly flooded the ground under the tube to check radiation. All the photographs will be developed shortly in Cairo in the Survey Department.

There was no opportunity to organise observations at the north and south limits, or on the shadow bauds, but the Survey Department took six-hour magnetic readings according to the international scheme and a register of solar radiation.

The Lick Observatory party, under Professor Hussey, carried out their full programme, obtaining eight plates with a 40ft. lens, eight plates for intra-Mercurial planets with a composite battery of four telescopes, and one plate of the general coronal spectrum. The Russian party took four plates of the corona and a photographic register of magnetic elements.
The change of temperature was very slight, and a dead calm prevailed.

Tha corona was of the distinctly maximum type, with the longest streamer to the southeast, about two diameters at most, probably less, and three others shorter. Query, was the longest streamer over the recent sun spot. The corona seemed small to the eye, perhaps owing to haze or dust and the low sun. There was no sign of Mercury to the eye, nor was the moon seen at sunrise here.

div.head: ANOTHER SUICIDE.
div.p: At about 6.30 p.m. yesterday a young European girl, who is believed to have been a servant, threw herself into the sea opposite the "Cafe du Quai." The waves carried the body to a point opposite the "Cafe Falerne" where it was seen by a number of persons who had collected there. The coast guards had already telephoned to the police of the Menchieh caracol, who for some time did nothing, and, according to the official report could not recover the corpse till about 11. p.m. Bye witnesses inform os that the body was perfectly visible and might have been recovered with little difficulty, and that the efforts made by the police on the spot were so feeble that it was not till after 4 am. this morning that it was finally brought to shore.

The discrepancy between the statement made by the police and that of eye witnesses is so great that we venture to call the attention of the authorities to it If the corpse could have been recovered between 9 and 10 p.m.,as our informants asseverate, it would surely have shown better feeling had the police risked a wetting. The idea that a dead body should be allowed to drift about within a few yards of the shore for hours is so repugnant, that we prefer to suppose that our informants did not take into account the roughness of the water near the new quay. In any case the affair seems to require further explanation.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt-Col C. J. Markham and off, the band of the 1st Batt King's Royal Rifles will perform the following programme of music at the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow (Friday) evening, commencing at 9 o'clock.

div.head: THE STATE RAILWAYS. THE SUPERIOR COUNCIL. RETURN TICKETS.
div.p: As we announced in our issue of the 36th June last the present board of administration of the State Railways will shortly be replaced by a Superior Council, which will be presided over by Mustapha Pasha Fehmi, Prime Minister. We understand that the constitution of the council as reported by us on that date is correct. The date for the formation of the council will not be decided upon until the return of Lord Cromer and the chief Government officials.

M. Imblon, secretary to the board, will retire on pension as soon as the change is effected, and will be replaced by Mr. Spiers, who was lately engaged in England. Mr. Spiers, who possesses the necessary technical knowledge for the post will draw a salary of £1,000 a year.

The question of the re-issue of return tickets on the State Railways has been for some time under consideration, but as there is a divergence of opinion on this point between the members of the Railway Board, the matter will remain in abeyance for the present It is, however, no indiscretion to state that the return tickets will most probably be introduced with the new year, but then only on the principal lines, such as Cairo and Alexandria, Cairo and Port Said, and possibly also on the Suez line. Measures will be taken to prevent the recurrence of the frauds that were formerly practised on the railway administration, and that wore the cause of the abolition of return tickets, these frauds having been committed with the connivance of some of the petty employes.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS CO.
div.p: The Cairo tramway company are expecting next month from Europe a consignment of fifty cars of a new and improved pattern. These bars contain a special compartment for first-class passengers, with eight seats, which is situated at one end, and a similar compartment for ladies at the other, whilst the centre will be for the second class passengers. They will be put on the principal lines at as early a date as possible after the cars have had the motors fitted at Boulao.

We gave a short time back a detailed list of the several extensions and new lines the company are going to add to their present system. The first two to be taken in hand will be the prolongation of the Khalig line from the present terminus at Daher to the avenue Abbas, ending at the Gamrah bridge, and the extension in the opposite direction of the same Line as far as the abattoirs.

For the prolongation of the Boulao line from its present terminal point at the landing stage of the Ghezireh Palace ferry to the railway workshops, it will be necessary, in consequence of the narrowness of some of the streets in that locality, to construct a river embankment which will be 150 metres in length and 30 metres wide, which is estimated to cost £6,000.
According to the new concession granted by the Government these three extensions will have to be ready for traffic in one year from the 23rd July next

The company has paid the Ministry of Public Works the sum of' £3,500 towards the expense of widening the road from Foum El Khalig to the point where the new bridge to Rodah Island is being constructed,and £50,000 is the amount agreed upon to be paid by the company for the privilege of crossing the island from Old Cairo to Ghizeh when the new bridges

div.head: A NEW BIBBY LINER.
div.p: There was launched on the 31st August at Messrs. Harland and Wolff's Yard, Belfast, the twin-screw steamer Herefordshire (a sister ship to the Worcestershire), with the advent of which the well-known Lancashire and Yorkshire disappear from this service, single screw boats being now recognised as obsolete for first-class passenger traffic. The fortnightly service of the Bibby line will therefore be conducted entirely with twin-screw steamers of high power and the latest type.

Of oourse the Bibby patent tandem cabin is in fall evidence, for it has been so generally appreciated that practically all the leading mail lines, whether going east or west, are adopting the system for their new tonnage.
The Herefordshire is intended to sail on her maiden voyage early in the spring, and will thus be available for the busy homeward pas-

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Malta yesterday morning and is due at Alexandria on Saturday afternoon with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The S.S. Belgravia left Malta yesterday morning and is expected to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday evening with passengers and mails.

The Russian mail steamer Tsarita will leave Alexandria on Wednesday next at 10 a.m. for Piraeus, Smyrna, the Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa, and will connect with the mail steamers of the tame company for Sebastopool and Anatolian, Caucasian, Crimean, and Sea of Azov ports.
The M. M. mail steamer Congo, which left Alexandria on Friday, arrived at Marseilles at 6 a.m.. yesterday.
The S.S. Sailor Prince left Manchester on Tuesday with passengers and general Cargo and is expected to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 21st inst.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
SHIP ON FIRE IN THE CANAL.
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.

From various sources I learn the following details of an accident which occurred between kil. 13 and kil. 34 daring last night. It appears that the S.S. Chatham, having some 70 odd tons of dynamite on board, which entered the Canal here early last evening, was' tying up to permit the passage north of the S.S. Clan Camming. Before the manceuvre was quite completed the Chan collided with her, and in so doing, it is alleged, knocked down a lamp which was suspended in the Chatham's forecastle. The whole of that part of the vessel was soon in flames, and the proximity of such a large quantity of explosives decided; the crew of the ship to at once leave her ; two or three have since arrived here.

The chiefs of the Suez Canal Company, with characteristic energy, made a11 preparations for what might easily prove to be one of the most dreadful accidents on record The ex-plosion from whatever cause of such an enor mous quantity of dynamite would, of course completely destroy the canal for a great distance on either side, and the removal of debris would have entailed the work of weeks in all likelihood. All the powerful tuge and boats were at once sent down to the scene or the disaster, and both M. Reynold and M. Schmidt, the chiefs at Ismailia end Port Said, respectively, proceeded at a lata hour to the

All train service was suspended, and fresh water canal sluices were closed in case an explosion should oocur, and both from north and south ,Canal navigation was stopped. There are now some sixteen ships tied up in the canal and several others at either end awaiting passage.

After going carefully into the matter it was finally decided to make a dart at the ship with all the available pumps, with the idea of flooding the hold in which the explosives Were stored,—the fact of the crew having left the ship to herself making it more difficult.
The fire Was seen to diminish early this morning, but shortly after took a fresh hold and as I write the full power of the pumps is being employed to flood the ship.

div.head: ANOTHER BIG TOW.
div.p: The S.S. Berlin which left here today with three blades of her propellers gone was taken tow of the Altona when she reached the the open sea. She is being towed the whole voyage, but probably will use her one blade.
The tow lines consist of heavy wires at each end, which suspend between the two vessel a length of chain cable, this last giving a decided spring to the otherwise practically rigid wires.

div.head: THE ELDORADO THEATRE.
div.p: The Giuseppe Gray dramatic troupe are giving a saries of performances at the Eldorado Theatre which is proving very successful, and attracts nightly a considerable number of theatre-goers. Amongst the most popular pieces they have given have been Pillole d' Ecole, Il Foranito di Venezia, and Romeo and Juliet.

div.head: PASSENGER LIST.
div.p: Arrivals.
Arrived at Port Said by P. and O. S.S. Mol-davia from Singapore on Tuesday : —
Capt. Anley, Mr. M. Stewart, Mr. E.R. Carlos.
Arrived at Port Said from London by P. and O. S.S Arcadia on Tuesday :—

Hassan Abdel , Mr. H. O. Bennett, Mrs. L. Holeman and infant, Capt M. J. Hamilton, Mr. E Murchland, Mr. B. Hornsley ; from Marseilles : Mr. Sharpe, Mr. B J. H. Ottley, Mr. E Teller, Mr. Hopkins, Mr. Rumbold, Col. J. R. P. Lord, Mr. and Mrs. Marksad, Mrs. W. Chaplin, Miss Margerison, Mrs. R. P. Gallimore, Mr. G. H. Morrison, Mr. P. G. Barnard, Mr. C. J. Flower, Mr. R H Armine.
Arrived at Port Said from Brindisi by P. and O. S.S Isis yesterday :
Mr. and Mrs. S. Cookson.
DEPARTURES.
Le paquebot Prince Abbas de la Khedivial Mail, parti hier apres-midi pour le Piree, Smyrne, Metelin, Dardanelles et Constantinople avait h bord :

M.M. Stephan Cohidan, Georges Rini Bey, N. Donnison, T. Corotaili, N. Nanopoulos, E Drakos Alecco Bereketti, Dr. J. Tammis, D. Malaccas, C. Cangos, Hassan Bey Rassim, Bey Rassih, A. D. Taxousai, Michel Zottos, D. Chrissoverghis, Stephan Frudachis, B. Schual, M et Mme E Tirman, M. et Mme Jacques S, Alguadich et famille, M. et Mae Nikitas Petilos et famille, Mmes Sultana Agnantiadon, M. Oregon, M. Young, G. Min-ohenson, ainai que 111 passagers de pont.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The view taken by the Stock Exchange of the signing of the peace treaty between Russia and Japan was naturally one of general satis-faction and shares of all descriptions was immediately started, and a good deal of excitement unsued during which prices steadily rose all around. Of the stocks of the two belligerent nations, Russia seemed to forge ahead mors than the Japs Now, after the first excitement is over, busi-ness seems to be steadying down again, and in some quarters 'disappointment is expressed that the rise did not continue. This, however, does not apply to the Russian and Japanese stocks, the former of which have been bought in Paris, on the belief that the Russian Fours trill before long be quoted at 100 again. Japanese stock closes firm at 105 and the new loan at 95.

It is reported to-day that the arrangements are nearly completed in America for the issue of a farther Russian loan, and in view of this, Russian securities will be kept up. If the statement is correct that Japan will not issue a new loan, we shall see a further steady and permanent rise in their securities.

The markets close quiet and almost dull the effect of the Cronier failure still being felt. Consols have not kept up to the highest and they close to-day at 90. Other gilt-edged securities remain steady with a firm The firming up of money is no doubt due in a certain measure to the fear that the final financing of the war expenditure in the far East will tend to affect the rates in Paris, Berlin, eta

Egyptian stocks and shares are still influenc-ed to some extent by the Cronier fiasco, and even National and Agricultural fallen. We understand that a meeting of the directors of the Societe das Sucreries d'Egypt was held in Paris two days ago, at which the affairs of the Company were fully discussed. No definite news as to what took place has yet transpired, but in as much as the legal advisor of the Company in Egypt was present, it is supposed that measures are being taken to strengthen the future position of the concern. The action that it is said is about to be taken by the several banks and bankers who discounted M. Cronier's bills and those drawn on the Societe Sucraries d'Egypt and the Raffi-nerie Say may have very serious these concerns, as they may be held res-ponsible for the signatures given by their late director. Daira Sanieh stock finished today at and Daira Sugar 4 1/2 1/2.

Egyptian mines remain quiet with a slightly easier tendency, although Nile Valleys have risen to over £l per share since our last, thus justifying our remark that holders wotdBprohíba prohíba do well to average at the low price which they touched last week. Um Rus are easy at 7/8 ; New Egyptians are firm at 1 1/2, and Egyptian mines at 13.9. The recent rise in Nile Valleys has been attributed to a belief that the company has successfully made arrangements for the taking up of the 47,000 reserve shares that Mr. Robinson refused under his option, but the "Financial Times" states to-day that it is informed that no arrangement has yet been concluded as to the placing of the balance the company's unissued shares, bet that shareholders will at once be informed whenever anything definite is arrived at Neither was anything known by the officials to confirm the various rumours in circulation in the market as to favourable developments on the com-pany's concession.

div.head: LONDON COMMERCIAL REPORT.
div.p: Gum Arabic —Of 57 packages 15 sold, Aus-tralian fair frosted part rather Woody at 26' 6d, block at 15s ; remainder withdrawn of bought in, including picked Trieste peas at 8a. Gum Benjamin.—31 oases bought in.
Gum Elemi- 29 packages bought in.
Gum Edphorbium.—20 bags bought in.
Gum Kino.—6 cases' bought in.
Gum Myrrh.—Ot 53 packages 5 sold, Aden part blocky at 92s. 6d.
Gum Olibanum. — 23 cases sold, without reserve, garblings and sifting at 20s to 20s 6d, blocky garblings at 10s 6d.
Gum Saudrac.----- 10 cases, bought in, Mogador pickings at 40s.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: REGATTA.
The following is the result of yesterday's races for the Commodore's cups :---
The wind was moderate from the N.W. and a close finish in both classes was witnessed.
